research-plan/research-plan.html.title: Research Plan
research-plan/research-plan.html.description:
Last updated 7.3.2025 Summary Janne W. Matilainen (janne.matilainen@lapinamk.fi) University of Lapland - Faculty of Social Sciences Lapland University of Applied Sciences - Smart Built Environment Research field: Social Sciences - Management/Organization Studies Keywords (YSO): actor-network theory, innovation system, innovation policy, regions, research and development operations, university of applied science The Universities of Applied Sciences (UAS) in Finland have an applied and regional role in the Finnish innovation systems. Their research, development and innovation (RDI) activities are changing, gaining maturity and beginning to find their characteristic ways of operation. One of these ways are the service concepts branded around some core demand or competence, which conduct RDI in co-operation with small and medium enterprises (SME) utilizing applied and practical methods. Their purpose is to aid commercial actors with their industry-recognized problems to grow regional competitiveness. This research aims to understand how these applied RDI service concepts work socio-technically, and to examine their role in their respective UAS and more broadly in regional and sectoral systems of innovation. The research adopts a social constructivist views of technical innovation to explain the inner workings of these RDI organizations in relation to relevant innovation systems. Main theoretical backgrounds and lenses are those of actor-network theory (ANT) and systems of innovation (SI). The research is a case study with an ethnographic nature, based on actor-network theory, avoiding purely social or technological explanations. The study utilizes traditional qualitative methods associated with ethnographies. The case to be studied are the service concepts of TEQU and Frostbit in Lapland UAS. The deliverable result is a rich description about networks, interactions and translations in and with these technologically oriented RDI organizations and the relevant innovation systems. These objectives can be valued as societal, as the UAS’s RDI role in the national innovation system is in motion. Innovation systems can be seen as complex networks of actors and institutions that interact to create, facilitate and disseminate knowledge. The impacts pursued with this study are to evoke discussion in both theoretical and societal dimensions. Theoretical discussions this research contributes are innovation management and diffusion of innovations. Societal discussion it partakes in is innovation policy and the role of UAS’s in innovation systems in Finland. Premise underpinning the research: The project is a continuum of previous research done about Finnish UASs, RDI and innovation systems. Research’s premise is that the Finnish UASs ways of practicing RDI with SME-oriented service concepts is interlinks and participates in building innovation systems and their competitiveness, and that instead of purely technological or academic work they construct solution-oriented socio-technical ensembles that differ from the more traditionally held linear innovation models. Research questions: in the context of public-private RDI-activities performed by the Lapland UAS in regional settings. What are the actor-networks of the RDI service concepts? What do they consist of and how are they formed and maintained? How they define goals and what leads to their perceived success or failure? What are the key characteristics that enable or constrain their innovation processes? How do they relate to some perceived "innovation systems"? Do the RDI-activities enact innovation systems? What is their role in regional competitiveness? What kinds of models of innovation do they hold?
See attached Toulmin Argument. Expected research results: The aim and objective of this project is to create an ANT and SI inspired rich socio-technical ethnographic description about these kinds of service concepts (possible case studies: TEQU & Frostbit of Lapland UAS) in relation to and their roles in different systems of innovation. Work plan and schedule: The project is to be done as a part-time research, working full-time with the Lapland UAS.
See attached link to the Gantt-chart. Research data and methods: Observation notes, interviews, surveys and public & internal documents. The rich description is constructed with qualitative ethnographic methods, utilizing an actor-network theory -type of framework. The data to form this description is collected with participative and non-participative observations, interviews and surveys. Document analysis is also used to aid and supplement the qualitative interpretation. No codified preliminary data, but a six-year working experience about the RDI service concepts in question, which hastens the formal observatory methods’ implementation. Short comparative or enriching inquiries about The Research Institute of Measuring and Modelling for the Built Environment (MeMo) and Jamk University of Applied Sciences are also possible. Informed consent is gathered from the participants, and their right and ways to modify or withdraw that consent is informed and ensured. Data considering any participants/subjects is anonymized and handled according to good practices on the type of data in question. Monograph: A body of texts will be produced in hypertext/markdown format in Obisidian environment. Interlinked body of hypertext builds a type of a "Wiki" or "pattern language" about the research. The monograph will be compiled mainly from these texts. Risk assessment: Main risk for implementation is the possible delay of the project due to part-time research. The research is thus designed to have as little timing-sensitive parts as possible, to enable flexible and resilient implementation. No ethical issues or ethical reviews foreseen. Self- and faculty monitoring practiced. Scientific: The scientific impact pursued with this research is to “open the black box” of RDI in Finnish UASs in regional systems of innovation. It aims to renew the discussion about technically oriented RDI work in these types of institutions and their stakeholders, with not purely technological or social reasons, but taking to account them both. According to bibliometric searches there is little research about these types of organizations in frameworks of ANT and management, but the project is not novel as an ANT or STS study and no special potential for scientific breakthroughs is expected. Open science: Open-access wide-audience publication (publ. type E/D) at the start/mid phase of the project to market the project and promote societal discussion. Lapland University Consortium open-access channels are preferred, in Finnish. One publication in wider-audience professional or scientific publication (publ. type D/B). Open-access publications considering Universities of Applied Sciences are preferred, joint publication with stakeholders or academic partners favored, in Finnish or English. Open-access publishing of Obsidian library/vault as a "digital garden", to communicate the research "in the making". Beyond academia: Discussion with Universities of Applied Sciences, Regional Councils and other RDI funders, SME's and RDI policy makers are promoted.

headers.heading: Unboxing the RDI from Innovation Systems

research-plan/table-of-contents-for-mono.title: Table of Contents for Monograph
research-plan/table-of-contents-for-mono.description: Caution DRAFT 28.12.2024 #partiallyAIgenerated Background, Context and Intentions: Sets the stage for the research topic, its significance and potential impact. Scope of this Research: Defines the scope and focus to provide direction, discussions it participates and justifications for the research. Research Questions: Clearly states the central research questions guiding the study. Conceptual Framework: Briefly outlines the chosen theoretical lenses/frameworks and their relations and justifies their use. Background Theory: Focal Theory: Data Theory: On Form and Content: Elaborates and comments on the structure, contents and style of the dissertation. Overview of Relevant Literature: Reviews existing literature related to the research topic and chosen approach. Introduction to Systems of Innovation: Briefly outlines SI framework, including core tenets like systems thinking and interdependencies. Introduction to Actor-Network Theory: Briefly outlines the core tenets of ANT, including key concepts and their application to study Systems of Innovation. Applications in Previous Research: Reviews existing research related to the research topic using similar approaches. Critical Engagement: Discusses key debates and critiques within ANT scholarship, supplemented with SI and NM and their alternative perspectives. Research Design: Describes the chosen research approach (e.g., ethnography, case study etc.). Case Study: Introduces the specific case or phenomenon under investigation. Data Collection: Details the methods used to gather data (e.g., interviews, non-/participative observations, document analysis). Data Analysis: Explains how data will be analyzed through an ANT lens (e.g., identifying actants, mapping networks, analyzing translation processes) and how it identifies the innovation system. Ethical Considerations: Presentation of Empirical Findings: Tracing the Networks Dynamics: Analyzes how the actants interact, form alliances, and influence each other within the network. Translation and Inscription Processes: Identifies and analyzes how meanings, interests, and resources are translated between actants. Key Events and Transformations: Findings and Interpretations: Summarizes the key findings of the study and discusses their implications in the light of chosen approach. Theoretical and Practical Implications: To the Field of Study: Explains how the study contributes to the development and application of ANT and SI and discusses the broader implications of the findings for the relevant field of study. To the UAS' and Policy Makers: Limitations of the Study: and FRIN Summary of Key Findings: Briefly restates the main findings and contributions of the study compared to the research questions. Concluding Remarks: Offers final thoughts and reflections on the research, limitations, and potential avenues for future research.
research-plan/table-of-contents-for-mono.sourcePath: Research Plan/Table of Contents for Monograph.md

research-plan/toulmin-argument.html.title: Toulmin Argument
research-plan/toulmin-argument.html.description:
Grounds
Empirical observations reveal a network of heterogenous actors working in a setting that aims for the development of regional competitiveness.
And sinceWarrant
The flux of these actions constitutes as the practical enactment and materialization of social reality.
On account ofBacking
Actor-network theory (and after) and innovation system studies.
And becauseQualifier
These grounds can be seen as a description of the social reality of innovation systems.
SoClaim
Finnish UAS's RDI concepts actively contribute to the construction and realization of regional innovation systems
UnlessRebuttal
We deny this type of description having explanatory power over the social reality.

index.html.title: Index
index.html.description:
This website is for publishing my research project while it happens. During the research i build a body of texts in a format of hypertext, with a language called Markdown. What that means, is that these texts link into each other constituting a non-linear repository where the contents relate to each other. For a taste of this you can jump straight into my Research Plan or see examples of similar (or way fancier) implementations in the Digital Garden text.
All of this is managed in a personal knowledge base system called Obsidian. This repository in Obsidian is called a Vault. When it's published, it can be described with terms such as Digital Garden, Pattern Language or even Wiki. This site has been translated straight from my Obsidian Vault into a WWW-publishable HTML with Nathan George's HTML Export Plugin. It is then hosted in and published with GitHub and it's Pages functionality. Info This is very much a work in progress, and not everything that i produce will be published right away. This site itself is a static epoch of my Vault and has to be updated into the web whenever needed. The project has been started: 1.1.2025 Last web update: 8.3.2025 Caution The functionalities of this website are not perfect. Due to technical restrictions of the plugin when translating from Obsidian flavoured Markdown to HTML (with all the third-party plugins that i use), it does not mirror my Vault perfectly. Main problems being: Site's layout has it's quirks, f.e. listings may have unnecessary line breaks Citations might be presented as Pandoc format citation keys instead of human-readable citations
The schedule written in Markwhen does not work in web view. Contact Janne W. Matilainen Lapland University Consortium Rovaniemi, Lapland, Finland 66°28'51"N 25°43'18"E
janne.matilainen@lapinamk.fi

zotero_literaturenotes/@bignettiactornet.title: @bignettiActornetworkTheoryMethodological2023
zotero_literaturenotes/@bignettiactornet.description: Cite Bignetti, B., De Souza, A. C. A. A., & Petrini, M. (2023). Actor-network theory: Methodological issues in practice. Qualitative Research in Organizations and Management: An International Journal, 18(2), 142–162. https://doi.org/10.1108/QROM-05-2022-2337 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: Bignetti, Bernardo Author:: De Souza, Ana Clara Aparecida Alves Author:: Petrini, Maira ~ Title:: Actor-network theory: methodological issues in practice Year:: 2023 Citekey:: bignettiActornetworkTheoryMethodological2023 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Qualitative Research in Organizations and Management: An International Journal Volume:: 18 Issue:: 2 Pages:: 142-162 DOI:: 10.1108/QROM-05-2022-2337 Link . Abstract Purpose This study demonstrates a practical use of Actor-Network Theory (ANT), showing methodological, predictive and unforeseen issues that emerged during the data collection and analysis phases and how they were addressed during the development of this research. Design/methodology/approach Based on the research of reapplication of a “tecnologia social” (TS) of entrepreneurial education, this article explores the author’s reflections on the adoption of ANT as a theoretical-methodological approach, highlighting the practical implications of a social material theory during fieldwork. Findings The adoption of ANT places the researcher in front of methodological issues not always foreseen in the research design. Four moments to a practical path through the engagement of ANT agency are highlighted: the network of actors, monitoring of actors, interpretation of data collected and writing results. These moments correspond to methodological issues that the authors faced during the practical journey of the research. At each moment, the challenge aroused is discussed and the methodological choice chosen to address the issue is presented. Originality/value The engagement with ANT has enormous potential in the study of management and organizations phenomenon, but its methodological implications in practice are still challenging. The authors seek to share this investigation and engagement in ANT so that other researchers have a reference and a starting point to employ and engage in this theoretical-methodological lens. Thus, it may be possible to anticipate certain difficulties in future research designs and to glimpse at potential developments and paths that the research may lead. . .

zotero_literaturenotes/@delaetzimbabwebu.title: @delaetZimbabweBushPump2000
zotero_literaturenotes/@delaetzimbabwebu.description: Cite De Laet, M., & Mol, A. (2000). The Zimbabwe Bush Pump: Mechanics of a Fluid Technology. Social Studies of Science, 30(2), 225–263. https://doi.org/10.1177/030631200030002002 Synth Contribution:: Related:: Md FirstAuthor:: De Laet, Marianne Author:: Mol, Annemarie ~ Title:: The Zimbabwe Bush Pump: Mechanics of a Fluid Technology Year:: 2000 Citekey:: delaetZimbabweBushPump2000 itemType:: journalArticle Journal:: Social Studies of Science Volume:: 30 Issue:: 2 Pages:: 225-263 DOI:: 10.1177/030631200030002002 Link . Abstract In this paper we investigate the intricacies of an admirable water pumping device - the Zimbabwe Bush Pump B' type - so as to find out what makes it an appropriate technology'. This turns out to be what we call the fluidity' of the pump (of its boundaries, or of its working order, and of its maker). We find that in travelling to intractable places, an object that isn't too rigorously bounded, that doesn't impose itself but tries to serve, that is adaptable, flexible and responsive - in short, a fluid object - may well prove to be stronger than one which is firm. By analyzing the success and failure of this device, its agency and the way in which it shapes new configurations in the Zimbabwean socio-technical landscape, we partake in the current move in science and technology studies to transform what it means to be an actor. And by mobilizing the term love for articulating our relation to the Bush Pump, we try to contribute to shaping novel ways of doing' normativity. . .

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_siteName.description: The name of the vault / exported site

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
